Key Match Events: Ryan Porteous was sent off and Kai Havertz converted the resulting penalty kick.
Florian Wirtz scored in the 10th minute, becoming Germany's youngest Euros goal-scorer at 21.
Jamal Musiala doubled Germany's tally nine minutes later after combining well with Havertz.
Kai Havertz scored a penalty to increase Germany's lead.
Niclas Füllkrug scored Germany's fourth goal.
Emre Can scored Germany's fifth goal in stoppage time.
Scotland managed to score a late own goal off Antonio Rüdiger.
Post-Match Reflections: Germany captain İlkay Gündoğan expressed satisfaction with the team's performance and the start of the tournament.
Germany coach Julian Nagelsmann stated that it was a very good start and they can build on this.
Scotland's Steve Clarke acknowledged that his team did not play to their standard and needs to improve for the upcoming matches.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Franz Beckenbauer was honored before the match.
The capacity crowd included German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier, Scotland First Minister John Swinney, and Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán.
